WRITING.TEXT: In a word, factors. Ten is only divisible by two numbers, but twelve can be divided evenly by 2, 3, 4, and 6. You don't have to break out the decimal points if you want to divide into thirds or fourths like you do with base-10, and that has a lot of useful applications in normal life.
True, I think that's the reason we have 24-hour days.

It has to do with diminishing marginal returns. When you already have some measure of CDR then adding more will give you smaller and smaller fractions. Let's say you have a skill with a base 30 second cooldown. If you find a bunch of CDR-rolled gear you manage to get that down to 24 seconds. Adding a gem to that would only give you 12.5% of that 24 seconds, not the full 30, which comes out to a smaller sum. Does that makes sense?

OK, if it's actually *your* road, then that's fair enough. That's your road and you can maintain it as you see fit. My question is, how do you enforce who is or isn't allowed to utilize it? It wouldn't make sense to buy and maintain a road that anyone can use, because the wear and tear would be exactly the same, only now you're footing the bill instead of Uncle Sam. So it must be made for you and maybe a few buddies you want to stay connected to. So then how do you protect against trespassers? Presumably tax-funded police and highway patrols aren't an option, being government goons and all. You'll have to personally hire someone to patrol your road, as well as fences and other active or passive defenses. Alternatively you could do it yourself, though I imagine you'll be plenty occupied doing whatever you do to pay for all this stuff.
I'm not saying you can't find ways around these complications, but it does seem like a lot of extra effort just to not be a hypocrite.

It's just a pithy way of saying that, contrary to what successful people will tell you, a big part of success has to do with being in the right place at the right time. I have a spurious theory that the casual wasteland that is men's fashion of the last few decades is what gave rise to the m'fedora look. Young men don't want to wear suits everywhere like the old movies, but *do* want to accessorize and add a certain flair to their look without traditionally feminine trappings like jewelry. Antiquated gender coding notwithstanding, I absolutely see where they're coming from and would support it if the fedora itself wasn't specifically a dress hat that doesn't combine with your Dragonball-print Hawaiian shirt any more than cuff links combine with biker shorts.

So Inarius is basically the "father" of all humankind, having fallen in love with a demon named Lilith to produce the first of the Nephalem. This first generation was strong enough to beat angels and demons, and Inarius feared their strength so he used a powerful artifact called the Worldstone to weaken them over the centuries, eventually settling into the normal humans we're familiar with. But very rarely, a human is born with the original Nephalem strength. It's only happened twice in history, the first being centuries before the games with a guy named Uldyssian, who fought Inarius and won. As a result of his downfall, he was captured by the forces of Hell and tortured (as mentioned above).

This is what allows me to think Sean Connery's character in The Rock was actually his own James Bond persona, years later. That character was James Mason who took up the James Bond mantle just before the events of Dr. No in 1962. That movie ended with him and his sexy ladyfriend being captured by the US Coast Guard and detained in Alcatraz. Mason escaped and returned to MI6 just in time for From Russia With Love and the subsequent Connery-era movies. News of his escape came to light in 1973 and he was recaptured and interred, just in time for the Bond mantle to pass onto Roger Moore. There in Alcatraz he languished for 23 years until he was called upon to help Nic Cage fight terrorists.
Most of this actually lines up surprisingly well with what you learn about James Mason in The Rock.

I know nobody asked, but I'm going to attempt to explain it because I'm studying for my CCNA and explaining the concepts helps me as much as anyone else.
So, three of those numbers the IT guy said (the ones with the format xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx) are Internet Protocol addresses, which is used by a router to know where it needs to send information. The last one (the 00:80:0E:FF:EF:23) is a Media Access Control address, which is literally burned into the network interface card of your computer, or in other words your computer's "physical" address.
Any IP address that begins with a first octet of 127.xxx.xxx.xxx is called a "home" or loopback address, that individual computers may use for testing and local troubleshooting.
The 192.168.1.xxx address space is similarly reserved as a private address, used only by computers communicating on its own small network (for example, within the company), but not by anything else outside. In order to reach anything on the internet, the router will take that private IP and translate it into a valid "external" address that can go out without confusing other routers.
So to recap, his address is usable only by his local network, the home address is universal to every computer using IP, the physical address is intrinsic to his computer and can't be changed without replacing the card, and the external is an address he can use on the internet.

I don't doubt that's going on, but I don't think it's the whole story. Consider the Bill O'Reilly controversy right now. You can see it as a cynical decision to can him when the lost revenue from his advertisers pulling their support outweighs the draw from his audience, but it's proof that those advertisers are listening to the will of the people, if only because that's where the money is. Corporations are just machines following the money; since more people are thinking left-of-center than ever before, catering to that mindset is what will net them the highest profit. It's cold, it's logical, and for the purposes of making progress, it's fine by me.

There aren't a lot of people who have been to all fifty states, so it's hard to say. Personally I had my best years for the two I was stationed in Guam, which isn't even really a state.
Edit: shit, didn't answer why. Short answer, I'm inclined toward tropical weather and the people were some of the friendliest I've ever known to strangers. The downside is it's crazy expensive since everything is imported, the speed limit is 35, and if you don't give yourself something to do you could have island fever really quickly.
None of that really bummed me though, so it was a good time.

Reddit is one of the ten most widely trafficked websites in the entire world (or thirty, depending on whose doing the counting), but is consistently the largest of its kind. Ask yourself, if this community is as close to a random sample of the developed world's population as the internet has, and on average it tends to skew towards the left, what does that say about me? Is the entire world unusually liberal, or am I just unusually conservative? Occam's razor.

WRITING.TITLE: What is an important lesson from history that isn't being heeded in the modern world, but should be?

WRITING.TEXT: Area Damage procs 20% of the time, every time an enemy takes damage as long as the damage is not from a proc (ie, if you do the damage, not your items). It deals a percentage of that damage (the AD you have on your gear) to every other nearby enemy, up to a maximum possible of 194%. If enemies are tightly bunched then having high Area Damage can deal the pain with extreme efficiency, sometimes as high as 4x your base damage.
Keeping it Parental Guidance.

Hey, sometimes you gotta kite the boss :) Besides, horse archery has its limitations. They aren't great for sieges, which were the majority of military operations in the Middle Ages (open field battles where the horse archers excel were rare). The Mongols' real strength was in their adaptability; when they came to a dug-in fortress, they tended to just build their siege engines right there on site, only to abandon them afterward.
